dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROLYN, mid-40s, is standing in the doorway of the farmhouse watching a car drive up the road towards her. A LAWYER is unloading a briefcase from the trunk of his car. As the car approaches, Carolyn smiles. She steps out of the doorway and heads for the car, out of which exit her brother MICHAEL and his country girl wife BETTY, a stout buxom chatterbox. Both boast Florida tans and fashion styles.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (to Carolyn) Explain to me again why we didn't do this in Des Moines in an air conditioned office? —~ CAROLYN Mom's orders.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Is that the lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: (nods) I have some sandwich fixings if you're hungry.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (proudly) No, we just had lunch at the hotel with my brother and his new wife. She told me all the dirt. I. forgot how interesting things can get around here. It was so good to see them. The last time we visited they were in Europe. He is doing so well. He ordered champagne. For lunch! I nearly died.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I nearly died when I had to pick up the check. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Michael doesn't understand. People who make the kind of money my brother makes don't carry money on them. They keep it all in various accounts.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Then we should have had lunch at the bank. Carolyn tries not to laugh. Betty shoots him a dirty look, then stops take in the house and its surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Boy. It sure has been a long time.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (correcting her) We were here two Christmases ago.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Well, that's a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that long.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (suddenly upset ) Well why don't I just say black so you can say white! (to Carolyn) Don't be surprised to find your brother hasn't changed an iota. He hardly ever talks and when he does it’s in that tone! You should have heard him at lunch -- not two words until the bill came and then he says, ‘Worth every penny.’

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (defensive) So!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (angry) i i onet Like you were angry at me, at my brother, at the world for forcing you to eat a nice lunch! (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (starting to cry) I simply cannot stand that tone!

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: (sympathetically) Come inside. You're just tired from the trip. : She comforts Betty, who indulges in the attention.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I’ am so sick and tired of apologizing and not knowing what I've done!

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I'm sure you haven't done anything. Have some iced tea. How are the kids? .

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: We dropped them off with Betty's mom. Where's Steve?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: (uncomfortably) He's not coming. Betty suddenly stops crying and abrasively focuses on Carolyn's problems.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Aw, is he still cheating on you, hon? Carolyn suddenly loses sympathy for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lawyer hands Michael a document.

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: Just sign here as having received the contents from the safe deposit box. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRIDGES OF MADISON COUNTY - Rev. 10/12/94 4.

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (as Michael does) And this one, which clears the bank of all further responsibility for the contents. Betty whispers to Carolyn.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: This is kind of exciting. You think we'll find out your mother had secret millions lying around? Carolyn smiles weakly. Michael hands back the papers. ee LAWYER All right. Why don't we begin? He takes out Francesca'’s Last Will and Testament.

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: Your mother has been interred at Cedar Heights Funeral Home until arrangements can be made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Carolyn) I thought everything was arranged.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Well, there's a problem.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What problem?

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: Your mother left explicit instructions that she wished to be cremated,

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Cremated?!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Eeeww!

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I know. I don't understand it either.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: When did she decide this? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRIDGES OF MADISON COUNTY - Rev. 10/12/94

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: (reading will) Apparently just before her death.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Well, that's crazy. I don’t know anybody who gets cremated.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Lots of people do.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Well, no one in my family did! Dad bought cemetery plots at Prairie Hills. One for him, one for Mom.

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: It clearly states in the will --

dialogues.speaker: . MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I don't care what it says! Maybe Mom was delirious, you know. She didn't know what she was saying. If she wanted to be cremated, why the hell did she let Dad buy two plots, huh?

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: Well, she was very specific. She wanted her ashes to be thrown off Roseman Bridge.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: How bizarre!

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Mr. Peterson, are you sure Mom wrote all this?

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: Well, it was notarized and witnessed by a Mrs. Lucy Delaney. Maybe you can ask her.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Who the hell is Lucy Delaney?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I remember a Mrs. Delaney but Mom told me years ago she died. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2a

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Well, I don't care if it's legal or not, we're not cremating her and throwing her off some bridge where we can't even go visit her because she's going to be blown all over the place like an ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Not to mention people driving over her and doggies doing their business -- °

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (interrupting) . We're not doing it! I'm not even sure it's Christian.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Maybe it's an Italian thing. (to Lawyer) . Their mother was Italian.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter. Move on. The women dare not object. The lawyer raises his eyebrows and continues:

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: Well, we'll come back to that. Shall we open the box?

dialogues.speaker: LATER .
dialogues.text: A key is inserted and the lid is opened. There are many papers, deeds, etc. Michael begins sorting through these. Carolyn notices a manila envelope addressed to her mother postmarked 1965. She opens it up to find two letters and a photograph -- Francesca standing near a covered bridge, her hair wind-blown, her expression serene, beautiful and sad.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Michael, look -- I've never seen this picture of Mom, have you? Betty and Michael look over her shoulder. He shakes "no." (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: It was in this envelope from 1965.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: She's not wearing a bra. (takes bridge photo) This is Holliwell Bridge, in case anyone's interested. Interested, yes, but no one thinks anything of it. Michael returns to the other papers. Betty takes the photograph for further examination. Carolyn opens one of the letters and begins to read. The following dialogue is heard 0.S., as CAMERA ANGLES ON Carolyn reading one of the letters:

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It's a beautiful picture of her.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (to Lawyer) Why are there two deeds here?

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: One is for the original parcel your father bought and this one is for the additional acres he purchased in '59.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And this?

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Those are bills of sale from the equipment your mother sold in... Their conversation continues 0.S. Throughout their conversation, we FOCUS ON Carolyn as she reads and her expression sinks into one of shock and confusion. She flips to the last page of the letter to read who it is from. She can't believe her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What's that? Carolyn. jumps a little, so engrossed in her discovery. She lies.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Oh, just an old letter from a friend. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (laughs ) No treasure maps, huh?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: (laughs nervously) No. Betty starts inspecting knick-knacks around the house she might be able to take. Carolyn looks to Michael.

dialogues.speaker: . CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Michael.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (reading documents) Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Michael.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (irritated) What !?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Come here a minute. Michael crosses impatiently to Carolyn. Carolyn looks around to the others, then guides him 0.S. into the kitchen for privacy. He protests.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What? Where are we going? They exit. Alone with the impatient Lawyer, Betty examines a vase as she pumps him for info.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Did she say anything in there about me? Leaving me anything in particular?

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: No. Betty prattles on as she examines each item, much to the Lawyer's dismay, hiding her resentment and hurt. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2a

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I didn't expect so. She never liked me. It's okay. I always knew. Thought we married too young. Nobody broke his arm -- that's what I said, but you know mothers and sons. Also, she never liked the fact of us moving to Florida although that's where the opportunities were. Couldn't deny that. Suppose we should have visited more but you know she hardly ever made an effort to come to Tampa. Not even to see her grandchildren. She was a cold woman. They say Italians are hot blooded but not her. She was ~ cool as ice. (picks up a candlestick) She leave these to anyone? Michael and Carolyn reenter the living room. Michael's expression now matches Carolyn in disbelief. Grateful,

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Um... we were just wondering how it might be better if Carolyn and I went over the stuff by ourselves. Not keep you two waiting around. I'11l contact your office about the legal work. the Lawyer packs up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I don't mind waiting.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Well, there's a lot of boring stuff to do. Lists of people we have to write to. Find Mom's relatives' addresses in Italy -- stuff like that.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Well, I can help.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I said no! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: That came out a bit aggressively. Betty is hurt.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Why don't you go to your mother's? Or back to the hotel. Sit in some air conditioning. Take a bath.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (near tears) I do not need instructions from you to bathe! (gets her bag) I knew you'd do this! I knew I'd come all the way here and be shut out as usual! I came to be here for you! I didn't have to come! (genuinely hurt) Lord knows I was never much welcome in this house before. Apparently dead-or alive, nothing's changed.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Aw, Betty. Carolyn feels badly for her. An impatient Michael refuses sympathy. Embarrassed, Betty starts to exit, then stops at the mantle.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Carolyn -- you want these candlesticks?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: No. I'd like you to have them. Betty grabs them both and exits. Carolyn looks at him disapprovingly. Michael takes the letter from her hands.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Now what's this about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting at the kitchen table, Carolyn is in the middle of reading the letter to Michael. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: il.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: '... going over and over in my mind every detail, every moment of our time together and I ask myself, "What happened to me in . Madison County?" I struggle to put it together in a way that allows me to continue knowing we're on Separate roads. But then I look through the lens of my camera, and you're there. I start to write an article and I find myself writing it to you. It's clear to me now we have been moving towards each other, towards those four days, all our lives --'

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (rises) I don't want to hear anymore! Burn the damn thing! I don't want to hear it! Throw it away! Carolyn continues reading silently. Michael's curiosity gets the best of him.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What's he saying now?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Well, he just goes on about how if Mom ever needed him, she could find him through the National Geographic Magazine in Washington, D.C. He was a photographer. He promises not to write again. Then all it says is... (beat) I love you... Robert.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Robert! Jesus! I'11 kill him.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: That would be some trick. He's already dead. That's what this other letter is. (takes letter and skims ) From his attorney. He left most of his things to Mom and requested... She stops. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That he be cremated and his ashes thrown off Roseman Bridge.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: amn him! I knew Mom wouldn't have thought of that herself. It was some damn perverted... photographic mind influencing her! When did the bastard die?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Wait a minute! That was three years after Daddy. Do you think...?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'm completely in the dark here. That's what I get for moving away.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: This happened way before we both got married. I... I can't believe it. (then, innocently) You think she had sex with him? Carolyn cannot believe he is this dense.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) My Lord. It must feel real nice living inside your head with Peter Pan and the Easter Bunny.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Don't talk to me like that. She was my mother, for Christ's sake. And now I find out she was... She was. a --

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Don't say that!

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Well what am I supposed to think? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I can't believe she never told me? We spoke at least once a week. How could she do that?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: How did she meet him? Did Dad know? Anything else in that envelope?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: No, I don't think so. I -- She dumps it over and a small key falls out. Pause, as Carolyn and Michael look to each other -- they grab the key and run out of the kitchen, almost comically falling ever each other in their obsession to put this puzzle together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM one lock TO another as they try to find the keyhole that fits the key -- they try closets, attic doors, jewelry boxes, night tables, vanity drawers... Finally --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the foot of their parents’ bed sits a walnut hope chest, covered with a tapestry. Michael and Carolyn look to each other first, before one removes the tapestry and the other tries the key. It fits. They open the chest to find: Camera equipment, a chain with a medallion that reads "FRANCESCA," three leather bound notebooks -- and a sealed envelope with "Carolyn or Michael" written on it.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN/MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You read it! Carolyn relents. She takes out the letter and reads:

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: "January, 1987. Dear Carolyn. I hope you're reading this with Michael. I'm sure he wouldn't be able to read it by himself and he'll need some help understanding all this.’ (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Insulted, Michael pulls the letter out of her hand and defiantly attempts to read it aloud himself to disprove his mother's claim. But after looking at a few lines, he surrenders and hands the letter back to his sister.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: "First, and most of all, I love you both very much and although I feel fine, I thought it was time to put my affairs, excuse that word, in order.'

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I can't believe she's making jokes.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Sshhh. ‘After going through the safety deposit box, I'm sure you'll find your way to this letter. It's hard to write this to my own children. I could let this die with the rest of me I Suppose. But as one gets older, one's fears subside. What | becomes more and more important is to be known -- known for all -that you were during this brief stay. How sad it seems to me to leave this Earth without those you love the most ever really knowing who you were. It's easy for a mother to love her children no matter what -- it's something that just happens. I don't know if it's as simple for children. You're all so busy being angry at us for raising you wrong. But I thought it was important to give you that chance. To give you the opportunity to love me for all that. I was...’ Carolyn and Michael look to each other like two school children about to take a difficult exam. They continue.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: "His name was Robert Kincaid. He was a photographer and he was here in 1965 shooting an article for National Geographic on the covered bridges of Madison County. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Remember when we got that issue? How we felt like celebrities? Remember when we started getting the subscription?’ They don't remember.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: "I don't want you to be angry with him. I hope after you know the whole story, you might even think well of him. Even grateful.'

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Grateful!?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: (reads) ',.. It's all there in the three notebooks. Read them in order. If you don’t want to, I suppose that's okay, too. But in that case I want you to know something -- I never stopped loving your father. He was a very good man. It's just that my love for Robert was different. He brought out something in me no one had ever brought out before, or since. He made.me feel like a woman in a way few women ever experience...'

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (cuts her off) That's it! Grabbing the. letter, he starts putting everything back in the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: This is crazy. She waits ‘til she's dead to tell us all this. Well, I got news for you. She was my mother. That's enough for me. I don't have to know who she was.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Well, I'd like to read them. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: No. We're going to lock this up and --

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: t (as Michael freezes) I want to read them! If you don't want to then just leave. But don't you push me around like I'm some mule you paid for -- I already hav ! Michael is stymied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carolyn opens the first notebook which is dated AUGUST 1965. Michael sits beside her with a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "It was the week of the Illinois State Fair. The two of you were going with Dad to exhibit Carolyn's prize steer.’ Carolyn's voice becomes Francesca'’s voice as we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANCESCA is making dinner. A BLUES station is tuned in on the RADIO.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "I know it sounds awful, but I couldn't wait for you all to leave. You were going to be gone until Friday. Four days... (beat) Just four days...' Francesca's expression looks as if she needs a break from her family for more like four years.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Michael! Carolyn! Richard! Dinner! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She sets down a bowl of potatoes, a plate of sausages, coffee and corn as one by one her family enters and sits down. Michael enters through a screen door from the back, letting the door slam shut.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Michael, what did I tell you about that door? Richard enters after Michael, letting the door slam the same way. Francesca is about to say something, but gives up. Carolyn enters and crosses to the kitchen RADIO. Leaning on the counter, she turns the dial to a COUNTRY station. This clearly irritates Francesca, but she knows there is no point in arguing. ~ Everyone sits and begins eating -- in complete silence except for the song. When Michael can't open the ketchup bottle, Francesca grabs it, palms the top skillfully and twists it off. She hands it back to Michael, who makes no comment. When Richard scans the table for something that obviously isn't there, Francesca is up out of her seat before he can ask, at the fridge, grabbing the sour cream, closing the fridge and back at the table with incredible swiftness. When Michael moves his big arm to reach for the salt, he knocks over his cup and saucer, which Francesca catches with both hands before they hit the floor. Her reflexes are like a trained athlete. Finally, Francesca is able to sit and sip her coffee. She watches her teenage daughter fill her plate with a blank expression that lets nothing slip through -- no indication of all the tempests of emotions that go through a teenage girl. FRANCE“SCA You excited about going, Carolyn? Without looking up, Carolyn fakes a smile. Francesca then looks to her son, shoveling food into his mouth at an alarming rate. She attempts a conversation.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: How was your date last night? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: _ MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (without looking at her) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: What's her name?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Betty.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: What's she like?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Okay. Silence. Frustrated, Francesca looks at Michael with dismay. :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca is packing Richard's suitcase. Richard is at his bureau. He is trying to open a drawer but it's stuck.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Damn drawer! Francesca crosses to him and ushers him aside. Holds onto the drawer nobs, she looks at Richard, pauses, then does a funny jolt with her body that makes the drawer slip out easily.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: You can’t get mad at it.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (to bureau, joking) I'm sorry. I shouldn't have yelled. May I get a handkerchief, please? Francesca chuckles as she closes up the suitcase. Richard takes out a handkerchief from the drawer and closes it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: You should stay away from anything too spicy. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Words are no longer required. They read each other's minds.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: And I want you to promise me...

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I swear. Only filters and no more than half a pack a day. I got my orders.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: (defensive) Doc Reynolds said you'd be a lot better off --

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I know, I know. I'm kidding. You sure you don't want to come? Francesca looks at Richard with complete conviction.

dialogues.speaker: _FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: I'm positive. -

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What are you going to do for four days as a woman of leisure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same thing I do as a hired hand, only with less help. Francesca realizes this has hurt Richard's feelings. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I won't be able-to sleep ya know. Can't sleep without you next to me anymore.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: It's only four days. He gives her a sweet peck on the lips. Francesca touches his face gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca waves as her family drives down the driveway in their truck, kicking up a cloud of dust. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: When the dust fades, the truck is gone, out the driveway and on the road. Francesca turns and heads back to the house. As it slowly comes into view from atop the corn husks, she stops. She knows the house is empty now. She feels both relief and uncertainty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone, dressed in her bathrobe, Francesca checks the front door. She crosses to the living room. Noticing two throw pillows on the floor, she arranges them neatly on the couch. She sits herself in an easy chair then flicks on a reading lamp and opens her book. After five seconds, she closes the book. She crosses to the TV and turns it ON, then turns it OFF before the picture tuned in. She turns and leans on the TV, flicking the ON/OFF switch ON and OFF as her mind wanders. She gets an idea. She crosses to the hi-fi and looks through several albums she got from her Columbia Record Club. But nothing inspires her and she quickly loses the desire for music. She's antsy. She has this time alone and she doesn't know how to spend it. She walks through the dining room, passing a china closet filled with fancy dishes and glasses. She stops. Shoved in the corner behind is an old, unopened bottle of brandy. She removes it, setting atop the dining table to open it, then quickly changes her mind and returns the brandy to its lonely spot on the shelf. CuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks into the kitchen and leans on the counter to turn ON the RADIO. She stands just like her daughter as she tunes in the BLUES station. She sits at the Formica table with a glass of milk and listens. A DOG SCRATCHES at the screen door. Francesca rises to let him in.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Where've you been!? They already left, ya know -- you missed them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He sits by her chair at the table. She sits down. He leans into her. She scratches his head.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: I don't know why you're so sweet on.me -- you know I don't like you. Of course, she does like him, she's just in a teasing mood. The MUSIC PLAYS. Francesca softens as she pets him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: You like this song?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca, wearing a simple house dress, has two rugs hung over the porch. She is beating them to get the dust out. It is a hot day. She stops to wipe her brow. She - grabs a glass of iced tea from off the porch, takes a sip then presses the glass against her chest. Francesca looks up to the sun to clear her mind. It is blinding. When she looks back out onto her driveway, her vision is momentarily blurred. Until, slowly, out of the blur, she sees: A truck driving toward her house, kicking up dust, like some phantom appearing through the etheric plane. She sips her cool drink and blinks to regain her vision. The truck comes down her driveway and stops halfway. Francesca watches with suspicious curiosity as: The truck stops and ROBERT KINCAID steps out. Flashing his blue eyes in her direction, he smiles and says: ROBERT . Sorry to bother you but I've got a feeling I'm lost. Francesca remains guarded.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Are you supposed to be in Iowa? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He laughs. 22. 10

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (laughs ) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: . FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Well you're not that lost. She puts down her tea and crosses to him.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I'm looking for a covered bridge out this way... uh... wait a minute -- He looks through a small notepad for the name. Francesca watches him intently.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Roseman Bridge?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: That's it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Well you're pretty close. It's only about two miles from here.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Oh, terrific. Which way?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Go that way and you will come to Cutter's where you turn left.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Cutter's?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Cutter's farm. Small house close to the road. Big mean yellow dog.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Yes, and then you just take that road until it forks -- I think less than half a mile.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Which fork? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRIDGES OF MADISON COUNTY - Rev. 9/7/94 23.

dialogues.speaker: . FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: The right and you go -- no. Not that fork, excuse me. Then you pass Peterson's -- Peterson's farm, and by the old schoolhouse you go left. It would be easier to tell you if the roads were marked.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Sure would. Pause as Robert awaits directions and Francesca scans a sudden impulse.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Well, I can take you if you want. Robert is pleased, but a bit surprised as is Francesca’ who anxiously recants:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Or, I can tell you. I can take you or tell you. It's up to you. I don't care. Either way. Robert smiles, finding her sudden nervousness charming.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: If I'm not taking you away from anything. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: . FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: No. I was just going to have some iced tea then split the atom, but that can wait. (as he smiles) I just have to get my shoes. Robert watches her as she turns and heads back to the house. He turns back to the truck and notices the mailbox -- MR. & MRS. RICHARD JOHNSON. He nods as if he knew all along and begins to make room on the front seat for Francesca. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca is slipping on her shoes when she suddenly stops. "What am I doing?" she asks herself silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca approaches the truck. On the door, she reads: KINCAID PHOTOGRAPHY -- BELLINGHAM, WASHINGTON. Robert is clearing away paper cups, banana peels, paper bags, photography equipment. In the back, Francesca notices a cooler and a guitar case.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I wasn't expecting company. Let me get this out of the way. He hauls a case of film from the front to the back. Francesca notices his tanned, muscular arm move in one graceful sweep.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Okay. All set. Francesca smiles. They both get into the truck.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Now, where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Out, then right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck bounces along on the rock road, lime dust filling the air. Kincaid and Francesca ride in silence. The truck passes a small farmhouse, and a large angry yellow DOG races alongside, SNARLING and BARKING. Robert looks at Francesca and grins.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: So far, so good. This way?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: That way. He follows her directions.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: There's a wonderful smell about Iowa -- very particular to this part of the country. Do you know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I can't describe it, I think it's from the loam in the soil. This very rich, earthy kind of... alive... No. No, that's not right. Can you smell it?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) Maybe it's because I live here.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: That must be it. It's a great smell. Francesca wants to know more about him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Are you from Washington originally?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Lived there 'til I was twenty or so, and then moved to Chicago when I got married.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Oh. When did you move back?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: After the divorce. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Francesca 26. 13

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: . ROBERT
dialogues.text: How long you been married?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Uh... ha... (can't remember) Umm... Long time.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Are you from here originally, if you don't mind my asking.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: No, I don't mind. I'm not from here. I was born in Italy.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Well, from Italy to Iowa ~- you don't look particularly Italian. (as Francesca smiles) Whereabouts in Italy?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: My mother was Austrian. We lived in a small town on the Eastern side, no one's ever heard of called Bari.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Qh, yeah, Bari. I've been there.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: (surprised) No, really?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. Actually, I had an assignment in Greece and I had to go through Bari, to get the boat at Brindisi. But it looked so pretty, I got off and stayed for a few days. Breathtaking country. is overcome by the idea of such freedom.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: You just... got off the train because it looked pretty?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Yeah. Excuse me a sec. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He reaches over with one arm, brushing slightly against her thigh. He opens the glove compartment and pulls out a pack of Camels and a Zippo lighter.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Like one? Francesca hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Sure, I'll have one. She takes a cigarette out of the pack. Robert drops the pack and, with the same hand, flicks open the Zippo and ignites it. Francesca leans over. The road is bumpy and a breeze blows through both windows. ee She cups her hands around his to shelter the flame. She feels his skin for a brief moment. She sits back and enjoys the ride and her cigarette as Robert lights up. Silence. They drive.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: So, how long you've been living here?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Long. (changes subject) You just got off the train and stayed without knowing anyone there?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (laughs ) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck stops. They exit. Robert takes out some equipment.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: This won't take long. I'm shooting tomorrow morning. I just need to ~ do some prep work.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: I don't mind waiting. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He smiles and takes his equipment to the bridge. Francesca slowly follows. She watches his body move. Catching herself, she stops. Robert sets up a tripod in the small ravine beneath the bridge, pointing a view finder up as he plans his shots. Francesca walks through the bridge, noticing lovers' name scrawled on the inside: CATHY & BUDDY 4 EVER ... ROSIE AND HANK TIL THE END OF TIME. Through a crack in one of the wooden planks, Francesca watches like a voyeur as Robert works. She sees him take out a hankerchief and wipe the sweat off his neck, then inside his shirt and around his chest. Without knowing where Francesca is, Robert speaks aloud:

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Is it always this hot? Francesca moves quickly away from the plank, like a Peeping Tom who's been caught. .

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: This time of year.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I have some cold drinks in a cooler if you'd like.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Oh. Would you like one?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Not right now thanks. Francesca heads back to the truck, grateful for something to occupy her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the truck, she scans for the cooler bag. She sees it next to a duffel bag. The bag's zipper is opened. She glimpses inside at Robert's personal things -- clothes, socks, underwear, shav.ng kit. Life magazines from July and August, one depicting the death of Adlai Stevenson, the other a cover photo of the Watts riots. Th guitar leans against the cooler. She grabs a soda from out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the bridge, Francesca looks for Robert in the ravine but he is gone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She looks through the bridge to the other end and sees only the tripod. No Robert. She walks through the bridge and out the other end. She finds Robert bent over, picking flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Oh! You caught me. He rises with a bouquet of wildflowers for her.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Thanks for your help. Francesca smiles, not knowing how to take this.

dialogues.speaker: . ROBERT
dialogues.text: Men still give women flowers don't they? I mean, as a sign of appreciation? I'm not that out of date, am I?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: No, not at all -- (suddenly) -- except those are poisonous.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: What! He flings the flowers down. He wipes his hands furiously.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I was kidding. Robert looks at her with a shocked smirk, secretly liking her strange behavior.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (smiling) Are you by nature a sadistic person? She laughs as she helps him pick them up. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driving back, Francesca sits with her feet up on the dashboard. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Robert drives while he fiddles with the RADIO. All he can find are COUNTRY STATIONS.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Looking for something in particular? There's not much of a selection.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I found this Chicago station -- before. Wait a minute...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: It's 1410. Robert reacts with surprise, then tunes it in. We hear a BLUES SINGER with a sax arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: That's nice.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Want another cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Sure. Francesca's having a great time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert's truck drives down the road and into the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Well, thank you for the kindnesses, Mrs. Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Francesca.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Francesca. Robert. Francesca nods, as if to say hello and goodbye in the same moment. She gets out of the car, closes the door, then asks:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Would you like some iced tea? CcuT TO:  17 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert fiddles with the kitchen RADIO, tuning in to the Chicago station. Francesca is making iced tea. Robert sits back down at the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Lemon?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Sure. With her back to him, Robert never takes his eyes off her. She turns and crosses to him, with the tea. .

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Thanks. Francesca smiles and sips her own. She watches him gulp down the tea so fast, some of it dribbles down the ide of his face and neck. Francesca finds it sexy. He empties it. .

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Would you like another one? Robert nods and pulls out his cigarettes. Robert lights up as he watches her fix-another iced tea. He watches her slip off one shoe, then the other -- never missing a beat of her preparation. He can't help eyeing her body. When she returns, she also has the flowers he picked for her arranged in a jelly glass. She places them on the table and sits.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Sure you want to keep those in the house?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry ahout that. I... ha . I don't know why I said that. (changing the subject) Where are you staying while you're here?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: A little place with cabins. The something-Motor Inn. I haven't checked in yet.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: And how long are you here for? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: As long as it takes. I might stay a week. No more I don't think. Where's your family?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: My husband took the kids to the Illinois State Fair. My daughter's entering a prize steer.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Oh. How old?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: About a year and a half.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: No, your kids.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Oh. Michael's 17 and Carolyn's 16.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Must be nice having kids.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: They're not kids anymore. Things change.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Everything does. One of the laws of nature. People are always so afraid of change. But if you look at it like it's something you can count on happening, it's actually a comfort. Not many things you can count on for sure.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: I guess. Except I'm one of the people it frightens.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I doubt that.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Italy to Iowa? I'd call that a change. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: (explaining) Richard was in the Army. I met him while I was living in Naples. I didn't .know where Iowa was. I only cared that it was America. And of course, being with Richard.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: What's he like?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: He's very... clean.

dialogues.speaker: . ROBERT
dialogues.text: Clean?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: (catching herself) No. I mean yes he's clean but he's also other things. He's a very hard worker. Very honest. Very caring. Gentle. Good father.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: And clean.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Yes. Very clean. They drink. Francesca thinks she sounds like an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: So you must like Iowa I guess. Francesca looks at him. She wants to tell the truth but holds back.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: It's... uh... uh... She stops. Robert smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Go ahead. TI won't tell anyone. Surprised, Francesca looks at him oddly -- as if he already knows and is giving her permission. Francesca is so taken by his understanding and acceptance, she lets the flood gates open, speaking faster than her mind can keep up -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Francesca the table 34.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: (without a pause) I'm supposed to say, ‘Just fine. It's quiet. The people are real nice.’ All of that's true, . mostly. It is quiet. And the . people are nice, in certain ways. We all help each other out. If someone gets sick or hurt, the neighbors pitch in and pick corn or harvest oats or do whatever needs to be done. In town, you can leave your car unlocked and let your children run without worrying about them. There are a lot of good things about the people here, and I respect them for those qualities. But... hesitates, lights a cigarette and looks across at Kincaid.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: It's not what I dreamed about as a girl. Kincaid is silent for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I scribbled something in my notebook the other day for future use, just had the idea while driving along. That happens a lot. It goes like this: ‘The old dreams were good dreams; they didn't work out, but I'm glad I had them.’ I'm not sure what that means, but I'll use it somewhere. So I think I kind of know how you feel. Francesca smiles at him. For the first time, the smile seems warm and deep. She surprises herself. She doesn't want him to go.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Would you like to stay for dinner? There aren't many choices in town and... anyway, you'd have to eat alone. So would I. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: That's very nice of you. I don't get many dinner invitations on the job. It would be a welcome change. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca rushes in and starts to disrobe, getting ready to shower and change for dinner. She glances out the window and sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert is at the water pump. His shirt is off and he is washing himself. We INTERCUT the two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca finds herself staring. He has a muscular, firm body. She watches how the water cascades over his body. How he seems so unashamed, so "in his skin,” moving with such strength and grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert pauses and looks out over the open pasture. The cold water feels good. Since the pump is in the back of the house, hidden from the road, no one can see him. INT.. BEDROOM . 19¢ Francesca continues studying Robert until she has to literally pull herself away from the window with such a force that she rams herself into a chest of drawers. Taking a breath, she pulls herself together.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous. She heads for the bathroom, quite composed, then, without warning, makes an immediate 180 degree turn and heads back to the window to sneak a peek. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Watching him, she is possessed by some very frightening feelings and runs from the window, into the bathroom, closing the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca is gathering some vegetables for dinner from her garden. Robert is at his truck, in his pants, changing into a fresh shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca is cutting up vegetables. Robert enters with some of his gear.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I'm just going to put some of this film in your fridge. Heat isn't too forgiving out there. He does. On the RADIO, TONY BENNETT sings "Wrap Your Troubles In Dreams." Robert approaches Francesca.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Can I help?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: (surprised) Help cook?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Sure. Men cook.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: (laughs ) Okay. They stand side by side. Francesca hands him a stack of carrots and a knife.

Tony Bennett's up-tempo TUNE PLAYS OVER a SERIES of IMAGES of Francesca and Robert as they talk and prepare dinner. A) Four hands side by side, cutting and chopping. Occasionally, a hand brushes against another as it reaches for something. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: B) Robert's hand gently touching Francesca's waist as he reaches around her for an onion. C) Robert brings in his cooler through the screen door. He makes sure it doesn't slam. Francesca makes a note of this. D) Robert opens the cooler and removes two cold beers, tossing one to Francesca. E) Francesca opening a new tablecloth and spreading it out on the table. , F) Francesca handing Robert plates from the shelf, their fingers only barely touching. END OF MONTAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert and Francesca are in the middle of dinner. But instead of the usual silence that surrounds Johnson family eating, Francesca is mesmerized by Robert as he manages to eat and tell a story. The scene begins with a laugh from Francesca. :

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (laughs ) --. No, wait, it gets better. He stands up and acts it out for her.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You have to get the full picture here. I have three cameras around my neck, a tripod in one hand and my pants down around my ankles. I thought this was a private bush. I look up and this gorilla is staring at me with what can best be described as the most lascivious expression I've ever seen on a body with so much hair. Francesca laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I freeze. 'Cause that's what they tell you to do. In this position. It comes towards me and... and... He stops awkwardly. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: It starts...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Oh, my God... (laughs ) You're blushing.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (mock hurt) . It's still a very sensitive memory for me.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Then what happened?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: We got engaged. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: I hope it was a female gorilla.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I hope so, too. We still write. Francesca is laughing so hard she can't breathe. Robert loves making her laugh.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: You ought to write these stories down.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Nah. L've tried. My writing's too technical I think. Problem of being a journalist too long is you stop giving yourself permission to invent. I better just stick to making pictures.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: "Making pictures.' I like that. You really love what you do, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: {nods, smiles shyly) I'm kind of obsessed by it, actually. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Why, do you think?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I don't know if obsessions have reasons. I think that's why they're obsessions.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: You sound like an artist.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: No. I wouldn't say that. National Geographic likes their wild life in focus and without any personal comment. I don't mind really. I'm no artist. I'd faced that a long time ago. It's the curse of being well-adjusted. I'm too normal.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: (supportively) I don't think you're normal. He looks at her in surprise. She catches herself again.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: I didn't mean that the way it sounded.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Well, let's just call it a compliment and move on. (changes subject) Did you love teaching?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Sometimes. When there was a particular student who made a difference. I know they're all supposed to, but it's not true. You tend to single out one or two you think you can contribute something to.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: And did you?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: I'd like to think so. I know one of them went on to medical school.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Why did you stop? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Francesca Francesca Francesca

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: My children. And Richard didn't like my working.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Do you miss it?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: I don't know. I've never thought about it... what was the most exciting place you've ever been to? Unless you're tired of talking about it.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You're asking a man if he's too tired to talk about himself? You don't get out much, do you? smiles, a little embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. That was...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: (overlapping) No. It's alright. I just meant, it might be a little dull for you, telling all this to some housewife in the middle of nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: This is your home. It's not nowhere. And it's not dull. smiles again, this time relieved.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Lets see -- my favorite place... settles in to listen, never taking her eyes off of him.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Well, it's the obvious choice but I think I'd have to say Africa. It's another world. Not just the people and ‘the cultures but the land, the colors you see at dawns and dusks -- and the life there. It charges every molecule of air. Francesca is fascinated, being drawn into his imagery. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's tangible -- the moment to moment of life and death, the co- habitation of man and beast, of beast and beast, who'll survive, who won't -- and there's no judgment about it. No right or wrong or imposed morality. It's just life. It's a voyeur's paradise really because those animals don't want anybody in their business. You can watch but at a distance. Robert smiles at her, sensing how in tune she is with his feelings.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: _My, God. How I'd love to see that.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: They have safaris for tourists now. Maybe you can convince your husband. Francesca smiles. There is an awkward pause between them.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: It's a beautiful night. Would you like to go for a walk?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Yes. That would be nice. He gets up and opens the screen door for Francesca, not letting it slam. Francesca looks like a teenager with first date excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca and Robert walk through the pasture. It is a beautiful night.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You've got it all right here, you know. It’s just as beautiful as any other place I've seen.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: What? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (indicating the night) This. ‘The silver apples of the moon, The golden apples of the sun.' Francesca looks at him with surprise.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: W.B. Yeats, 'The Song of Wandering Aengus.'

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Right. Good stuff, Yeats. Realism, economy, sensuousness, beauty, magic. Appeals to my Irish heritage. She watches him with great appreciation. He smiles at her. Instead of looking away, their eyes remain locked . for a moment. There is clearly an attraction. They simultaneously look away and continue walking. Francesca's heart is beating a mile a minute yet she can't deny she is enjoying herself. Walking side hy side in silence, Francesca turns back occasionally to look at her house as they get further away from it. Suddenly, the more distant the house becomes, the more frightened she starts to feel. Something inside her knows she's going too far with this man -- too far from home. Although a part of her wants it, she is surprised to find a larger part of her finds it too unknown. She stops. .

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: What's wrong? Francesca looks confused for a moment, not knowing what she wants. She can't move. She searches for a way out.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Would you like some coffee? .Or maybe, some brandy? Somehow Robert can sense her uneasiness. He obliges.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: How about both?  24 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is illuminated by a single light over the kitchen sink. Francesca moves about the kitchen preparing coffee -- dropping the coffee pot basket, spilling the grounds. She acts tense. Robert sits at the table opening the brandy bottle Francesca almost opened the night before, aware of her mood. There are two brandy glasses in the cupboard that Robert takes down. Francesca gets the coffee going then sets the table with cups and saucers.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You sure you won't let me help you with those dishes?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: (coldly) No. I'll do them later.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Francesca?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Francesca?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: We're not doing anything wrong, you know. Francesca freezes. He has read her mind again.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (smiles) : Nothing you can't tell your children about. Once again, he relieves her of fear and anxiety. He hands her a glass of brandy, raises his glass to shoulder level and moves it toward her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: To ancient evenings and distant music. Francesca takes a short breath, touches her glass to his and smiles a little. They sit in comfortable silence, enjoying their brandy and coffee, smoking a little. The soft sounds of a hot summer night fill the air ~- a PHEASANT CALLS from the fields, a DOG BARKS twice in the distance, CRICKETS quietly SERENADE and a moth flutters against the sink light.

dialogues.text: Carolyn and Michael have come to the end of a notebook.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: He's getting her drunk. That's what happened. Jesus, maybe he forced himself. That's why she couldn't tell us.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Oh, he did not. He's such a nice guy.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Nice? He's trying to sleep with somebody's wife.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I don't think so. And besides, something like that doesn't make you a bad person. He reminds me of Steve in a way. Steve's weak, immoral and a liar, but he's still a real nice guy. He just shouldn't be married. (laughs ) At least not to me. You getting hungry? I'm hungry. Michael nods, then speaks with sincere compassion.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I had no idea it's gotten that bad, sis.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Oh, don't feel sorry for me. Please. No one's forcing me to stay. ‘

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Then why do you? Carolyn laughs to herself -- she can't explain it to herself. She looks through the kitchen cabinets and gasps.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Oh, my God! I don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What? Carolyn pulls out a newly bought jar of Fluffernutter.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Wow. I bet it's been here since we were kids. You could probably spackle walls with it.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: No, look -- the expiration date is this year. She must have bought it recently. And it's not opened.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: She never ate this stuff. We used to have to beg her to buy it for us, remember? Realizing her mother did buy it for them, Carolyn's eyes fill up a little, her mother's death striking her for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over Fluffernutter sandwiches on white bread and coffee, Carolyn reads from the second notebook.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: ‘We sat sipping brandy. I thought if anybody walked through the door .now there'd be no explaining it. But I didn't care. I wanted to be like him. I wanted to know his secrets. How he lived this life of his. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We talked about his wife and I was jealous -- not of her -- but of his leaving.: His fearlessness. He knew what he wanted. How did he do that?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca sips her brandy. Robert sits across from her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: De you mind if I... ask you why you got divorced?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Not at all. TI wasn't around much... So why did I get married? Well, I thought it was a good idea at the time. Have a home base. Roots. You can get lost moving around so much.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: So what happened?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I never got lost. I was more at home everywhere than at one place. So I decided to think of myself as some kind of world citizen.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: You must get lonely at times.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Never touch the stuff. I've got friends all over the world. Good friends I can see when I want, if I want.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Woman friends, too?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I'm a loner, not a monk. Francesca averts her eyes, before continuing her investigation. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: You really don't need anyone?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: No, I think I need everyone! I love people. I.want to meet them all!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: That's the thing about Iowa. You pretty much meet the same ‘kind of person over and over so when Mrs. Delaney's husband is having an affair with 'that Redfield woman' the whole town wakes up.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I just think there are too many out there saying, ‘This is mine,' or, 'She's mine.’ Too many lines have. been drawn. :

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Doesn't it scare you?

dialogues.speaker: . ROBERT
dialogues.text: I don't know what's coming. And I don't mind. I embrace mystery.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Do you ever regret it? The divorce, I mean?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Do you ever regret not having a family?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Not everyone's supposed to have a family. —

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: But -- how can you just live for what you want? What about other people?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I told you, I love other people.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: But no one in particular. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Francesca She rises, 48.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: No. But I love them just the same.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: But it's not the same.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I know it's not the same. What you're saying is, it's not as good. Or it’s not as normal or proper.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: No, I'm just saying --

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (interrupting) I'm a little sick of this American Family Ethic everyone seems to be hypnotized by in this country. I guess you think I'm just some poor displaced soul doomed to roam the earth without a self-cleaning oven and home movies.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: (irritated) Just because someone chooses to settle down and have a. family doesn't necessarily mean they're hypnotized. Just because I've never seen a gazelle stampede doesn't mean I'm asleep in the world.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Do you want to leave your husband? is completely stunned and thrown off guard.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: No. Of course not. upset. Beat. Awkward silence. Suddenly there is tension between them.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: My mistake. I apologize.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: What made you ask such a question? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I thought that's what we were doing -- asking questions.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: (defensive) I thought we were just having a converstaion. You seem to be reading all this meaning into it. Meanings I must be too simple to uh... interpret or something.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I already apologized. Silence. Robert remains seated. Francesca remains at the sink.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Roseman Bridge at dawn, I'd better get going. . : (rises) Thank you for dinner. Pause. Francesca feels badly.

dialogues.speaker: . FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Listen, I'm sorry I --

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: No, no. Forgive me. I made a mistake. It was an inappropriate thing to ask. Francesca shrugs it off.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: I feel like something's been spoiled now. . Robert smiles and crosses to her. He takes her hand into both his hands.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: It's been a perfect evening. Just the way it is. Thank you. Francesca smiles. The possibility of a kiss hangs in the air between them until Robert turns to get his film out o the fridge. As he exits through the screen door, he stops. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Thanks for the evening, the supper, the walk. They were all nice. You're a good person, ‘Francesca. Keep the brandy toward the front of the cupboard, maybe it will work out after awhile. He smiles and exits, catching the screen door before it slams. Robert takes a few steps down the porch and turns.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: One thing, though -- don't kid yourself, Francesca. You're anything but a simple woman. Francesca doesn't move for a moment, then crosses to the door as if to run after him, when she is stopped by the PHONE RINGING. She picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Hello?.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Franny?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Richard, hi.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (V.Q.)
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Fine. Everyone settled in okay?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Just fine. We're all in one room. - Michael's on the couch and Carolyn's... (continues) She hears Robert's truck DOOR OPEN and CLOSE. She hears the MOTOR being turned ON. She half listens to Richard.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Uh-uh... good... hmmm... She hears the TRUCK DRIVING AWAY as Richard continues:

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We got our position in the fair. Not bad, although I would have liked to be third which is not too early and not too late. But I told Carolyn not to worry... (continues, if needed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca sits on the porch with a book in her lap, gazin out over the pasture. It's a hot night. She opens the top of her robe a bit. Feeling the air against her skin, she decides to open it a bit more. She gets an idea. Standing, she looks to see if anyone is around -- though rationally she knows there isn't a soul for miles. She turns off the porch light. With a brave and daring impulse, she sheds her bathrobe and stands naked under the night sky. The air feels good against her body. She opens her arms up against the night sky and moon like an Indian priestess. Suddenly, she starts hitting her body as mosquitoes begin attacking her bare torso. Thwarted, she quickly covers herself with a robe and runs into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca is in front of a full-length mirror, her robe opened, applying Calomine lotion to insect bites. Suddenly, she stops to notice her body. CAMERA ANGLES OVER her shoulder. It is the first time in years she has actually stopped to look and touch her body running her hands gently over her curves, her neck, down the side of her thighs, her face, her breasts. She stops. She closes her robe and shuts off the light. She sits on the bed. . She gets an idea and crosses to a jewelry box on her bureau. She searches through it, then removes a section to reveal another compartment. It is filled with things she hasn't worn in years -- out of date earrings, pins, etc... Lying amongst these items is an Italian-looking medallion on a chain. She holds it lovingly and puts it on. Crossing to the window, she looks out and she sees the water pump Robert used that day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca sits in her bathrobe at a writing table with a note in front of her. On it reads, "If you'd like supper again, ‘when white moths are on the wing,’ come by tonigh after you're finished. Anytime is fine.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A warm, clear, summer night. The sky is full of stars. Francesca, still in her bathrobe, is behind the wheel of her car. The headlights cut through the darkness as Jack the collie runs’ ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car headlights light the way as Francesca walks bare- foot towards the bridge. Jack lopes on ahead, checking things out. . Francesca tacks the note for Robert to the bridge. She considers taking it down a moment later, but decides not to. She gets back into her car and drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca is asleep in bed. At the sound of Robert's old pickup TRUCK DRIVING by, she stirs and opens her eyes. She listens until the sound of his WHEELS FADES OUT, then smiles and settles back into sleep.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGE
dialogues.text: The view of the bridge goes IN AND OUT OF FOCUS until we realize we are seeing it THROUGH Robert's camera lens. Once the FOCUS is SET, Robert notices something is tacked to the bridge. EXT. BRIDGE . He crosses to it hurriedly -- time for the perfect shot is running out -~- pulls it down, thumbtack and all, and shoves it into his pocket, unread. He returns to his camera to take his shots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca sits at the kitchen table in her bathrobe with a cup of coffee -- a comic portrait of shame and self- pity. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Her hair is a mess, she hasn't showered or dressed and she stares into space while listening to the bluesy Chicago RADIO station. The sink is full of dirty dishes she refuses to clean. Beside it is an ashtray of butts from the night before. She carries it over to the table and begins fingering for a butt to smoke in desperation. She lights up and stares into space. .

dialogues.text: Francesca is hoeing weeds in her vegetable patch, not far -—~from the house. Suddenly, she stops working, and looks toward the house. Is it the telephone? She listens care- fully, doesn't hear anything and goes back to her hoeing.

She hurries down from the tractor and runs toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kincaid in the booth. PHONE is RINGING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Hi. This is Robert Kincaid. Francesca catches her breath and leans against the counter, unsure and anxious about what is coming next. INTERCUT BETWEEN the two.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Got your note. W.B. Yeats as messenger and all that. I'm sorry I didn't call sooner, but I just read it. I stuffed the note into my pocket because the light was fading and I had to get my shots.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: (smiles, relieved) The light was fading.

dialogues.text: I accept the invitation, but it might be late. The weather's pretty good, so I'm planning on shooting the Holliwell Bridge this evening. It could be after nine before I'm finished. Is that all right? Francesca frowns but manages to keep her voice from betraying her disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Oh sure, get your work done; that's what's important. I'll fix something that'll be easy to warm up when you get here.

dialogues.text: If you want to come along while I'm shooting, that's fine. It won't bother me. I could stop by for you about five~thirty. Francesca pauses, then decides.

dialogues.text: Yes, I'd like that. But I'll drive my pickup and meet you there. What time? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.text: Francesca is thrilled. Her mind races with a list of things she must do before tonight. She opens a cabinet, removes a coffee can and empties it of her house money. She quickly counts it, then shoves it into her purse.

dialogues.text: Francesca drives past a sign marking DES MOINES as the next town.

He can sense their eyes on him, wondering who this stranger is and what's he doing here. He knows the whispered conversation is about him. A MIDDLE-AGED COUPLE talk at table.

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: Thelma told me he checked into the Motor Inn and the bill goes to ional aphic M ine.

dialogues.text: i 1 ic? What the hell's he doin' here? We ain't got no naked pygmies to take pictures of.

dialogues.text: Ain't no pygmies there either. Robert: wants to finish his lunch as quickly as possible. At that moment, someone enters the restaurant and all the conversation stops. He overhears one WAITRESS turn to a SECOND WAITRESS and whisper -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: God. It's Lucy Redfield.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: (whispering back) Apparently Mrs. Delaney caught them. The First Waitress gasps. WAITRESS #2° Ran right into them in Des Moines in the middle of her shopping. Robert's curiosity gets the better of him and he subtly turns his head to see: The REDFIELD WOMAN. But instead of being the harlot we might think, she's actually a rather plain, demure- locking woman. As she crosses to the counter, Robert immediately picks up on the vibes in the room. He notices all the patrons stare, then turn away to whisper. The Waitress behind the counter ignores her while the Second Waitress heads to the kitchen. A customer eating at the counter places a bag on an empty stool beside her, so the Redfield Woman can't sit down near her. Robert and the Redfield Woman's eyes meet. She is clearly uncomfortable. She turns, about to leave, when Robert clears his cameras off a stool next to him and offers:

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Got room right here if you like. She is surprised at his courtesy. Others are astounded. Some disgusted. She accepts his offer and sits beside him.

dialogues.speaker: REDFIELD WOMAN
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Hot out there today. She nods and smiles. The Waitress tosses a menu at her and slams down a glass of water, then moves on down the counter. The Redfield Woman tries to act casual, glancing through the menu. Robert subtly scans the room as all eyes are on them, then turns away. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Robert returns his glance back to the Redfield Woman who is now only pretending to read the menu. She is so embarrassed. She wants to leave but can't move.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Well, are you ordering anything!? Her harsh tone startles the Redfield Woman as well as Robert. Gathering her dignity, she responds:

dialogues.speaker: REDFIELD WOMAN
dialogues.text: No. Thank you. I've changed my mind. She politely nods to Robert, gathers her things and exits Robert looks to the Waitress, as the Second Waitress ENTERS FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd've thrown that water right in her face.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Poor Mrs. Delaney. The Waitress walks 0.S., leaving the Second Waitress facing Robert, who looks at her curiously. The Second Waitress looks back as if to say, "What business is it of yours?" and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A metropolis compared to Winterset. Francesca exits a liquor store with a bottle of wine in a paper bag. She also carries a bag of groceries as she heads down the street to her parked truck. She passes a dress shop and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert enters a general store. He buys a six pack of beer for his cooler and approachés the counter for the CASHIER (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: That all? Robert nods. He decides to have some fun and test the waters a little bit.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Isn't it awful about poor Mrs. Delaney? With this, the dam bursts --

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Tragic is more like it. The pain that woman has been subjected to by that no-good husband. I never liked him. Known him for years. People say he's quiet. Well, it's the quiet ones that can sneak up behind you and stab you in the back. I-heard yesterday, that she confronted him. Gave him the ultimatum and you know what he did? (continues as needed) Robert stands astounded, listening to this diatribe of gossip.

dialogues.text: Robert comes around Main Street to get into his truck whe he sees a 1957 Chevrolet a few spaces down from his. The Redfield Woman is sitting behind the wheel, the windows rolled up and she is sobbing. CAMERA MOVES IN ON Kincaid as he fixes on this moment.

dialogues.text: Francesca sits in her slip, alone in a dressing room, with several dresses strewn about. The panic of inde- cision has set in. She looks at herself in the mirror and begins to doubt that seeing Robert is a good idea. Or perhaps she's imagining something that isn't there. And what about Richard? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.text: Francesca feels guilty when a SALESWOMAN enters with 2 pretty summer dress.
