dialogues.text: How about this one? Francesca examines it. She likes it. But the guilt...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: I don't know. I haven't bought a dress for myself in so long. (off. saleswoman's nod) I mean, I'm just buying a dress. It's not a special occasion or anything. I'm just shopping. Just shopping for a new dress, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: SALESWOMAN
dialogues.text: (completely understands ) That might work. And if he's still mad, just tell him you could have done better but you married him out of pity. That always works for me.

dialogues.text: Francesca enters with her new dress, groceries and wine a the PHONE RINGS. She puts everything down to answer.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Hello? INTERCUT WITH Robert at a payphone.

dialogues.text: It's Robert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hi. Look, I'm running a little late, but I'll still...

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (with difficulty) Listen, don't take this the wrong way, but -- I'm wondering if this is such a good idea. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Francesca’ Silence. 60. 45 s heart sinks.

dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.text: I uh... I had lunch in town today. Happened to cross paths with ‘that Redfield Woman.'

dialogues.text: I guess you got the whole story...

dialogues.text: The cashier at the general store was very generous.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: I think he's running for town crier next year.

dialogues.text: I now know more about their affair than I remember about my marriage. (seriously) If it's a problem for you to see me tonight, given the curiosity of small town people, don't feel pressured to do it. I'm not always so bright about other people's reactions and the last thing I want to do is to put you in any kind of situation that would...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA

dialogues.text: Robert? (CONTINUED )

Eat at the diner' -- isn't that hilarious. (moves into kitchen) He didn't dare raise an eyebrow -- I don't even want to tell you how late he was out last night with those good-for-nothings from the Sandford ranch. I am so sorry, honey, I let two days pass before I came by but with the boy home the time just escapes me. Have you heard from Richard? How's the fair? God, it's hot. Following her into the kitchen, Francesca doesn't know which question to answer first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madge and Francesca sit facing the pasture beside a table with coffee and brown betty. We PARACHUTE INTO the middle of the scene.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: . I said to her, ‘What's the point of summer school if all he's going to do are these art projects. The boy needs so much work in math and his spelling is a nightmare... Madge continues. Francesca isn't listening. Her mind wanders. Madge shoves a plate at her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Francesca Francesca’ Francesca 81. 65

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: More brown betty? takes the plate. She can't think straight.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: ... Anyway, I'm glad that's over with. Sara's doing so well, though. Everyone thought I was crazy having them so far apart but... s mind races as Madge continues:

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: ... without one lesson. The instructor couldn't believe it. So, who knows -- she may have talent. How's Carolyn doing? What are her plans for next year? realizes this is her moment. She holds her head and leans over, unsteadily.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Honey, what's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: I don't know. I woke up a little dizzy: I didn't sleep well. I think I need to lay down.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: You want me to call the doctor?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: No, no -- I just didn't sleep well. I'm not used to sleeping alone. And this heat... Would you mind?

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: No, of course not. I'll just clean up.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: No, leave it. I'll do it later. Listen, maybe you and Floyd can come for dinner on Saturday. I'm sure Richard'll have so many stories to tell you both about the fair and all.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Oh, that'll be nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca enters to find Robert lying on the bed fully clothed. She sits beside him. He strokes her arm, then guides her to lie down. Once she's in his arms, he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Come with me. Francesca knew he was going to say this. Either answer she gives frightens her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Hold me. She turns to him and they embrace. Robert, however, fears only one response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC PLAYS OVER the next few images. CAMERA SLOWLY PANS FROM the RADIO, upon which the SONG is playing, TO a beautifully set table and candles. It ARRIVES ON Robert preparing dinner. He stands at the sink rinsing out some utensils. Waiting for the water to turn hot, he looks out THROUGH the window above the sink. He sees a beauti- ful view of the night. He pauses as it strikes him that this is a view Francesca has seen a million times -- that soon She would not see ever again.

dialogues.speaker: INT, BEDROOM
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS the room FROM two opened suitcases, as Francesca packs to leave. She is wearing a red dress, with buttons down the front. She moves about the room as if with blinders on -- focused on her task, refusing to take in any signs or memories that might hinder her. Francesca tries to open one of the bureau drawers and it gees stuck. She pauses for a moment, then gathers her bags. : CAMERA FOLLOWS her as she exits the bedroom with her suitcases, then walks down the hall to the stairs, then down the staircase to the front hall.  69 70 83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She quietly sets the suitcases down, hearing the RADIO “and ROBERT in the kitchen. She pauses, then enters the living room. One of the throw pillows has fallen off the couch, She replaces it, then takes a moment to look about the room. She slowly sits down on the couch. Robert appears in the doorway and stands there looking at her until she sees him and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I've got dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They eat in silence. Neither is very hungry. ROBERT © —_ Would you like a beer? : She smiles and shakes her head. Robert opens a bottle and takes a sip. The silence between them is becoming awkward. Pause. Robert takes another sip. Then, knowing full well what hangs heavy between them, he asks:

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You're not coming with me, are you? Francesca stops pretending to eat. She looks at him, having forgotten how well he can read her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: No matter how I keep turning it around in my mind -- it doesn't seem like the right thing.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: For who?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: For anyone. They'll never be able to live through the talk. Richard could never get his arms around this. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He doesn't deserve that. He hasn't hurt anyone in his life.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (getting aggressive) Then he can move! People move!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: His family's lived here for almost a hundred years. Richard doesn't know how to live anywhere else. And the kids...

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: The kids are grown! They don't need you anymore. You told me that. They hardly talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: No, they don't say much. But Carolyn's 16. She's just about to find out about all this for herself -- she's going to fall in love, she’s going to try and figure out how to build a life with someone. If I leave, what does that say to her?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: What about us?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: You've got to know deep down that the minute we leave here, it'll all change.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Yeah. It could get better.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: No matter how much distance we put between us and this house, I bring it with me... and I'll feel it every minute we're together. And I'll blame loving you for how much it hurts. And then even these four days won't be anything more than something sordid and... a mistake. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (desperately) Francesca, listen to me. You think what's happened to us happens to just anybody? What we feel for each other? How much we feel? We're not even two separate people anymore. Some people search their whole lives for it and wind up alone -- most people don't even think it exists and you're going to tell me that giving it up is the right thing to do?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: We are the choices we've made, Robert. Robert rises and turns his back on her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Robert. Please. (desperate) You don't understand -- no one does. When a woman makes the choice to marry, to have children -- in one way her life begins but in another way it stops. You build a life of details. You become a mother, a wife and you stop and stay steady so that your children can move. And when they leave they take your life of details with them. And then you're expected to move again only you don’t remember what moves you because no one has asked in so long. Not even yourself. You never in your life think that love like this can happen to you.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: But now that you have it --

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: I want to keep it forever. I want to love you the way I do now the rest of my life. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't you understand -- we'll lose it if we leave. I can't maké an entire life disappear to start a new one. All I can do is try to hold onto us both. Help me. Help me not lose loving you. She embraces him. He wraps his arms around her. He whispers.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Don't leave me. Don't leave me alone. Please, This breaks her heart, knowing how hard it is for him to say this. She holds him tighter, until --

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Listen. Maybe you feel this way, maybe you don't. Maybe it's just because you're in this house. Maybe... maybe when they come back tomorrow you'll feel differently. Don't you think that's possible?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: I don't know. Please...

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I'm going to be here a few more days. I'll be at the inn. We have some time. Let's not say any more now.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: No. Don't do this.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: ' lb ! We'll leave it for now. We're not saying goodbye. We're not making any decision. Maybe you'll change your mind. Maybe we'll accidentally run into each other and you'll change your mind.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Robert, if that happens, you'll have to decide. I won't be able to. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She cries in his arms. He kisses her as if for the last time. Then, quickly, separates himself and leaves the house. Looking back toward the house at Francesca:

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I'll never say this any other time, to anyone, and I want you to remember it. This kind of certainty comes only once and never again. No matter how many lifetimes you live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert walks briskly towards his truck, not wanting to look back. He gets in, STARTS IT UP and drives away. Francesca exits the house and watches the truck recede into the distance. She stops when she reaches the front gate, leaning against it. She murmurs to herself --

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Keep going. Please. The truck drives away. Then, suddenly, stops. Francesca's heart quickens. She watches as the truck stands on the road in the distance. As if Robert was deciding to turn around or keep going. Francesca waits. Suddenly, the door to the truck flies open and Robert exits. Francesca loses all restraint. She opens the gate but her dress is caught on it. Robert stands by the truck. Francesca tears at the dress, ripping off a button which falls to the ground. She runs down the road. Seeing her, Robert runs towards her as well. They grab each other furiously. For these few moments, all considerations are gone. CAMERA PANS UP TO the road beyond Robert's truck. We see Richard's truck driving towards them. For a moment it seems as if they will be caught until we realize Richard's truck is being SUPERIMPOSED as the light gradually brightens to reveal:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard, Michael and Carolyn drive down the road toward the house. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Robert's truck, and all traces of him are gone. Francesca steps into the doorway in a house-dress to welcome her family home -- wondering how this will feel. CuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Johnson family has dinner as Francesca narrates:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You all came home. And with you, my life of details.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is doing various daily chores,

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: A day or two passed and with each thought of him, a task would present itself like a life saver, . pulling me further and further away from those four days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca is reading. Richard watches TV.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I was grateful. I felt safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A light rain is beginning to fall. Richard and Francesca drive up to the general store to buy groceries. Francesca heads for the store as Richard crosses the street. : (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Want anything special for dinner?

dialogues.speaker: . RICHARD
dialogues.text: Hmmm. How about that brown sugar meat loaf you make?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: (smiles) . Okay. She enters the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca makes small talk with the grocery lady as she buys what she needs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain has gotten heavier. Francesca places a bag of groceries on the front seat of the truck, then gets in herself to wait for Richard. She takes a deep breath and removes a handkerchief from her bag to wipe the raindrops from her face. She freezes -- THROUGH the windshield, she sees Robert standing in the rain beside his truck across the street, staring at her. Her heart stops. For a moment, she isn't even sure he's real. . The town moves about its business around them. But neither notice or care. Whatever safety or forgetfulness she felt is gone. Her feelings burst through. She sits there helpless before him -- willing to go or stay depending on what he did. He begins walking towards her. She prepares herself. Her life will change -- it has to. There's no turning back. But the closer Robert gets, the clearer he can see that she is crying. And he stops. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Without any words, he realizes what taking her with him would mean. With just a glance, he sacrifices her. With their eyes locked in the middle of Main Street -- in front of the whole town -- they smile and say goodbye. Robert returns to his truck. He drives off, down Main Street. Moments later, Richard throws the feed bag into the back of his truck and gets in. Francesca is wiping her eyes. He doesn't notice. He drives off in the same direction as Robert.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: For a moment, I didn't know where Iwas. And for a split second, the thought crossed my mind that he really didn't want me -- that it was easy to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their momentum brings them up right behind the old pick- up, and sitting high in the Chevy, Francesca can see a black tarpaulin lashed down tight in the back, outlining a suitcase and guitar case wedged in next to the spare tire lying flat. The back window is rain-spattered but part of his head is visible.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Robert leaned over as if to get something from the glove box. Eight days ago he'd done that and his arm had brushed across my leg. A week ago I had been in Des Moines buying a new dress.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: That truck's a long way from home. Washington State. I'11 bet it's that photographer they been talkin’ about at the cafe. Francesca doesn't respond. She is struggling to fight back her tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They follow Kincaid a few blocks north to where 169 intersects with 92 running east to west. It is a two- way stop with heavy cross traffic, complicated by the rain. . (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: For maybe twenty seconds they sit there. Francesca's hand moves to the door handle.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Since Robert Kincaid had driven away from me last Friday, I realized, in spite of how much I thought I'd cared for him then, I had nonetheless badly underestimated my feelings. That didn't seem possible, but it was true. I had begun to understand what he already understood. Francesca sits frozen by her responsibilities, staring at that back window harder than she has ever looked at anything in her life.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What's he waiting for? Francesca looks up to see that traffic has cleared in all directions. But Robert doesn't move. Francesca knows he is going through the same thing as she is in that moment. And then she sees: Robert, knowing Francesca is watching, takes off the medallion and hangs it on his rear-view mirror -- touching it gently, as if he were touching her. Richard BEEPS his HORN lightly. But Robert's truck just sits there. Francesca's eyes begin to tear up. Her hand grips the door handle. She doesn't have the strength to stay -- and she doesn’t have the strength to leave. Suddenly, Kincaid's left signal light comes on. In a moment he'll be gone. Richard fiddles with the Chevy's RADIO. Robert slowly eases his old pickup into the intersection heading west, lowering his window to help with visibility Francesca squints through her tears and the rain and fog and sees the faded red paint on the door: "Kincaid Photography -- Bellingham, Washington.” As Robert completes the turn, Francesca can see his hair blowing in the wind from the open window. He begins to accelerate down 92 and rolls up the window.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: 'Oh, Christ -- oh, Jesus Christ Almighty... no!' (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The words were inside of me. 'I was wrong, Robert, I was wrong to stay... but I can't go. Let me tell you again why I can't go... Tell me again why I should go.' I heard his voice coming back down the highway...

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: This kind of certainty comes only once, and never again, no matter how many lifetimes you live. Richard takes the truck across the intersection heading north. Francesca looks for a moment past his face toward the old pickup's red taillights moving off into the distance. A huge SEMI-TRAILER RIG ROARS into Winterset, spraying a wave of water over the last cowboy.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: (whispers ) Goodbye, Robert Kincaid. She begins to cry openly. Richard looks over at her.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What's wrong, Franny? Will you please tell me what's wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Richard, I just need some time to myself. I'll be alright in a few minutes. Richard TUNES IN to the NOON LIVESTOCK REPORTS, looks over at her and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain is beginning to back off. Richard's truck drives up. Francesca steps out with her bag of groceries and walks briskly into the house. Richard follows more slowly with his bag of feed, stopping at the gate to pick up the button from Francesca's red dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca enters and places her groceries on the counter. She tries to compose herself. She sees the RADIO before her. She turns it ON. The DINAH WASHINGTON SONG, "I'll Close My Eyes" evokes every feeling of love and loss within her. She begins to cry. She hears Richard enter the house. She stands out of sight, holding her hand to her mouth to muffle her crying. She hears:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dad! You bought the wrong feed!

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What?! She hears Richard exit the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At dinner, Richard remembers the button he found.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Oh, Franny, is this yours? Francesca sees the button. She speaks to Richard MOS. The scene continues and her narration is heard:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I almost told him. In that moment I felt as if I couldn't hold it “back. If he really loved me, maybe he'd understand. She returns to her meal. The family eats in silence.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I was grateful for the silence that night. I realized love won't obey our expectations. Its mystery is pure and absolute. What Robert and I had, could not continue if we were together. What Richard and I shared would vanish if we were apart. But how I wanted to share this. How would our lives have changed if I had? Could anyone else have seen the beauty of it? cut TO:  82 83 84 94.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca moves about the kitchen with a frantic pace as she puts the finishing touches on a cake. Placing the frosting bowl in the sink, she hears SOMEONE UPSTAIRS exiting their bedroom. She quickly gathers the cake and her bag and exits through the screen door. CUT To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fighting tears, she walks to the TRUCK from around the house. She gets in and STARTS it. She vaguely hears her daughter from the front door:

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Mom? But she doesn't acknowledge it and drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand knocks on a door. LUCY REDFIELD opens it to find Francesca standing there with a cake.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Hi. I'm Francesca Johnson. I just feel awful that I haven't come to visit sooner. I hope I'm not interrupting anything. Is it too late? Lucy is shocked and moved at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: No. Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: I was wondering if... maybe you'd like some company. (almost manic) I baked a cake! Lucy looks at the cake. She's a little dazed by all this.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Uh... sure. Please. Come in. I'll make coffee. Francesca enters. Lucy closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael continues reading beside Carolyn as the sun rises.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: 'We became inseparable, Lucy and I. The funny thing is, I didn’t tell her about Robert until years later. But,-for some reason, being with her somehow made me feel it was safe to think about him. The town loved talking about the two of us but we didn't care. And neither did your father. Which I thought was a lovely thing. I received Robert's letter and my photograph soon after. I always wondered if your father found them. I was Never quite sure...’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An older Francesca cares for a sickly Richard. He lies in bed beside an array of medicines and tonics. She wipes his forehead with a cool cloth as he takes his pills.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Better? He nods. She smiles. She shuts off the light and lies beside him.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Franny?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Hmmm?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I just want to say... I know you had your own dreams. I'm sorry I couldn't give them to you. I love you so much. Francesca turns to him. She is so touched, tears fill her eyes. She nestles close to him, wrapping her arms around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca picnics at the same spot she shared with Robert.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: -After your father died, I tried to get in touch with Robert but found out he had left the National Geographic. No’ one seemed to know where he was. My only connections to him were the places we'd been to that one day. And so each year on, on my birthday, I'd re-visit them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca greets a UPS man with an envelope and a package.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: And then one day, I received the letter from his attorney, with a package.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francesca reads the letter informing her of Robert's death. She then unwraps the package to reveal a medallion with her name inscribed and a photography book; a published collection of black-and-white photos by Robert Kincaid entitled Four Days. Pressed between two pages, the note Francesca left for Robert on Roseman Bridge. We only see the words "white moths are on the wing." On the front page there reads an inscription, "FOR F.":

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: 'There is a pleasure in the pathless woods... there is a rapture on the lonely shore... There is society where none intrudes... By the deep sea and music in its roar... I love not man the less, but Nature more...' (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ",.. From these our interviews, in which I steal... From all I may be, or have been béfore. To mingle with the Universe and feel... What~™ I can ne'er express, yet cannot all conceal.' The quote is Byron's. She smiles with pride as she cries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael and Carolyn enter. He rummages through the — cupboard, finding that bottle of brandy, now almost ~ empty.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: There is enough for two drinks. Want one?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Yes. Michael takes the only two brandy glasses from the cupboard and sets them on the yellow Formica table. He empties Francesca's last bottle of brandy into them. The notebooks are closed, but Francesca’s narration continues over the next few scenes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There has not been a day since that I have not thought of him, When he said we were no longer two people, he was right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carolyn, looking through her mom's closet, finds the summer dress she bought in Des Moines to wear for Robert.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We were bound together as tightly as two people can be. If it hadn't been for him, I don't think I would have lasted on the farm all these years. Remember that dress of mine you wanted, Carolyn -- the one you said I never wore. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Well, I know I was silly. But to me, it was as if you were asking to wear my wedding dress to go to the movies. Carolyn smiles as she holds the dress before her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tired Michael finds his way through the motel to his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After reading all this, I hope you can now understand my burial request. It was not the ravings of some mad old lady. I gave my life to my family. I wish to give Robert what is left of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael enters to find his two children watching TV and an angry Betty folding clothes.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDREN
dialogues.text: Hey, Dad! . He looks at them lovingly, then at Betty, who angrily motions for him to follow her into the bedroom. She slams the door behind him and talks in an irate whisper:

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: You have been out all night long! Do I have a right to ask where you've been? Michael just looks at her. He gently takes her hand and kisses it.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Do I make you happy, Betty? (as she is stunned) Because I want to. I want to more than anything. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He gently kisses her cheek, then embraces her. Betty -- for the first time in her life -- is utterly speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearing her mother's dress, Carolyn sits on the bed hold- ing the phone, waiting for Steve to pick up. In her other hand, she holds the divorce lawyer's card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone; gently) Hi, Steve? It's me... Good. You...? Listen, we have to talk . Well, how about now...? Uh, no -- I've decided I’m going to stay for a while... I don't know how long... I'm not angry, Steve. I'm not angry at all... She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael and his family stand beside Carolyn and a Priest.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: "I gave Lucy his photography book. If you're interested, take a look. If my words still leave some things unclear, perhaps his pictures can illuminate. After all, that's what an artist does best.! Michael receives the urn from the priest. He and Carolyn walk away from the group towards the bridge. They stop. gazolyn removes the lid. Michael sets his mother's ashes ree.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: 'I love you both with all my heart. Do what you have to to be happy in this life. There is so much beauty. Go well, my children. ' FADE OUT.
